Hi all,
I would really appreciate some feedback on a small framework I'm
wr=
iting for JUnit 4.4.

I call it Bumblebee, and the purpose of it is to use =
comments and the
structures in the test-suites/cases/methods to create "hum=
an-readable"
documentation. It is especially well suited for writing snippe=
t-heavy
documentation.

In short, Bumblebee gets events from the execution =
of the tests
(suites/classes/methods) and then parses the classes and metho=
ds for
specific comments to include.

By default it adds the de-camelcased =
names of the suites/cases/methods
as headings (a la agile dox), and the con=
tained comments becomes the
paragraphs.

The comments are actually handled =
as Ruby-strings that get executed in
a Bumblebee execution context before b=
eing added to the output. The
execution context is
a kind of DSL for includ=
ing code-snippets and other things needed, and
one of the core ideas of Bum=
blebee is that you should be able to
extend that functionality easily.

Mor=
e detailed information about Bumblebee can be found at:

http://www.agical.=
com/bumblebee/bumblebee_doc.html

which is of course generated with Bumbleb=
ee. :-)

The concept of Bumblebee is the same as for TDDoc, which me and Jo=
akim
Ohlrogge wrote some time ago as an add-on for RMock. Unfortunately,
TD=
Doc became a bit of a dead-end technically, and Joakim and I thought
it wou=
ld be a good idea to start fresh. I happened to have the time at
the time a=
nd I started it up. So, if you like Bumblebee, give half of
your credits to=
 Joakim!

This is an early release, and I will be very happy for any feedba=
ck I
can get to improve it.

Cheers
Daniel Brolund
